canonical_explanation.text: The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms. Robert Hooke discovered cells in 1665 when he observed cork under a microscope. The cell theory states that all living things are made of cells, cells are the basic unit of life, and all cells arise from pre-existing cells. Cells have three main parts: cell membrane (controls what enters and leaves), cytoplasm (jelly-like substance containing organelles), and nucleus (control center containing genetic material). Cell organelles include mitochondria (powerhouse), ribosomes (protein synthesis), endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi body, and lysosomes. Plant cells differ from animal cells by having a cell wall, large central vacuole, and chloroplasts. Organisms can be unicellular (like Amoeba) or multicellular (like plants and animals).
rules: Cell is the basic structural and functional unit of life
Cell membrane controls entry and exit of substances
Nucleus controls cell activities and contains genetic material
Mitochondria are the powerhouse of the cell
Plant cells have cell wall, large vacuole, and chloroplasts
Animal cells lack cell wall and chloroplasts
Unicellular organisms have one cell; multicellular have many

questions.question_text: Who discovered cells for the first time?
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke discovered cells in 1665 when he observed cork under a microscope, which led to the development of the cell theory. This makes option A the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B (Anton van Leeuwenhoek) is incorrect because while van Leeuwenhoek was one of the first to observe cells using a microscope, he did not discover cells. Option C (Charles Darwin) is incorrect because Darwin's work was on the theory of evolution, not the discovery of cells. Option D (Gregor Mendel) is incorrect because Mendel's work was on genetics, not the discovery of cells.

questions.question_text: In which year were cells discovered?
questions.explanation_correct: Cells were discovered in 1665 by the scientist Robert Hooke, who observed cork under a microscope and saw many small compartments he called 'cells'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cells were not discovered in 1565, 1765, or 1865. Robert Hooke first observed and described cells in 1665 when he looked at cork under a microscope, which is why the correct answer is 1665.

questions.question_text: Which material did Robert Hooke observe under the microscope when he discovered cells?
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke observed cork under a microscope in 1665 when he discovered cells. Cork is a plant material, and Hooke was able to see the small box-like structures that we now call cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct because Hooke did not observe onion peel, human cheek cells, or blood under the microscope when he discovered cells. He observed cork, a plant material, and was able to see the small box-like structures that we now call cells.

questions.question_text: Which part of the cell controls all its activities?
questions.explanation_correct: The nucleus is the control center of the cell that controls all its activities. It contains the genetic material (DNA) that directs the cell's growth, development, and reproduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nucleus is the correct answer because it is the control center of the cell. It contains the genetic material that tells the cell what to do and how to function. The cell membrane, cytoplasm, and cell wall are important parts of the cell, but they do not control all the cell's activities like the nucleus does.

questions.question_text: The jelly-like substance inside the cell where organelles are suspended is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The jelly-like substance inside the cell where all the organelles like mitochondria, ribosomes, and Golgi bodies are suspended is called the cytoplasm. The cytoplasm is the region between the cell membrane and the nucleus, and it is where the basic life processes occur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cytoplasm is the correct answer because it is the jelly-like substance inside the cell that contains all the organelles. Nucleoplasm is the gel-like substance inside the nucleus, protoplasm refers to the entire contents of the cell (both cytoplasm and nucleoplasm), and cell sap is the watery solution found in the central vacuole of plant cells.

questions.question_text: The cell membrane is also called:
questions.explanation_correct: The cell membrane is also called the plasma membrane because it is the outermost layer of the cell and it surrounds the entire cell, controlling what goes in and out of the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell membrane is not the nuclear membrane, which is the membrane surrounding the nucleus. It is also not the cell wall, which is found only in plant cells and provides structural support. The tonoplast is the membrane surrounding the central vacuole in plant cells, not the entire cell.

questions.question_text: Which organelle is known as the 'powerhouse of the cell'?
questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria are known as the 'powerhouse of the cell' because they are the organelles that produce energy for the cell through a process called cellular respiration. This energy is essential for the cell to carry out its functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct option is Mitochondria. Mitochondria are the organelles that produce energy for the cell, which is why they are called the 'powerhouse of the cell'. Ribosomes are responsible for protein synthesis, the nucleus contains the genetic material, and the Golgi body is involved in the processing and packaging of molecules, but they are not the 'powerhouse' of the cell.

questions.question_text: Which organelle is responsible for protein synthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Ribosomes are the organelles responsible for protein synthesis in the cell. They are the 'protein factories' that produce the proteins needed for the cell's functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mitochondria are the 'powerhouses' of the cell, producing energy for the cell. Lysosomes are the 'recycling centers' that break down waste materials. Vacuoles are storage compartments, not responsible for protein synthesis. The correct organelle for protein synthesis is the ribosome.

questions.question_text: Which organelle is called the 'suicide bags' of the cell?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Lysosomes. Lysosomes are called the 'suicide bags' of the cell because they contain powerful digestive enzymes that can break down and destroy unwanted or damaged cell components.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct. Ribosomes are the organelles responsible for protein synthesis, the Golgi body is involved in packaging and transporting substances, and vacuoles are storage compartments in plant cells. Lysosomes are the organelles that contain digestive enzymes and are responsible for breaking down and recycling unwanted or damaged cell parts, which is why they are called the 'suicide bags' of the cell.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is present in plant cells but absent in animal cells?
questions.explanation_correct: Plant cells have a cell wall, which is a rigid structure made of cellulose that surrounds the cell membrane. This cell wall is present in plant cells but absent in animal cells, which only have a cell membrane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Cell wall. Plant cells have a cell wall, which is a rigid structure made of cellulose that surrounds the cell membrane. This cell wall is not present in animal cells, which only have a cell membrane. The other options, A) Nucleus, C) Cell membrane, and D) Cytoplasm, are all present in both plant and animal cells.

questions.question_text: Chloroplasts are found in:
questions.explanation_correct: Chloroplasts are found only in plant cells, not in animal cells. Chloroplasts are specialized organelles in plant cells that contain chlorophyll and are responsible for photosynthesis, the process of converting sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide into food for the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chloroplasts are not found in animal cells. Animal cells do not need chloroplasts because they do not perform photosynthesis. Chloroplasts are specific to plant cells and help plants make their own food through the process of photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: An organism made up of only one cell is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An organism made up of only one cell is called unicellular. This is because 'uni' means one, and 'cellular' refers to cells, so a unicellular organism is made up of a single cell that can carry out all the functions of life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An organism made up of many cells is called multicellular. Plant and animal organisms are examples of multicellular organisms. Unicellular organisms, on the other hand, are made up of just one cell that can perform all the functions of life, like an Amoeba. So, the correct answer is that an organism made up of only one cell is called unicellular.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a unicellular organism?
questions.explanation_correct: Amoeba is a unicellular organism, meaning it is made up of only a single cell. This is unlike rose plants, humans, and frogs, which are multicellular organisms made up of many cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The rose plant, human, and frog are all multicellular organisms, meaning they are made up of many cells. Amoeba, on the other hand, is a unicellular organism, which means it is made up of only a single cell. This makes Amoeba the correct answer to the question.

questions.question_text: A cell without a nucleus would not be able to:
questions.explanation_correct: The nucleus is the control center of the cell, containing the genetic material that controls all the cell's activities and allows it to reproduce. Without a nucleus, the cell would not be able to properly control its functions or reproduce.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not directly related to the presence or absence of a nucleus. Cells can still absorb water, store food, and maintain their shape even without a nucleus. However, without a nucleus, the cell would not be able to control its activities or reproduce, as the nucleus is the control center that contains the genetic material needed for these processes.

questions.question_text: If the mitochondria in a cell stop functioning, what would happen?

options.text: The cell would not produce proteins
The cell would not have energy

questions.explanation_correct: If the mitochondria stop functioning, the cell would not have energy. Mitochondria are the powerhouses of the cell, responsible for producing the energy currency (ATP) that the cell uses to carry out its activities. Without functioning mitochondria, the cell would not be able to generate the energy it needs to survive and carry out its essential processes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) The cell would still be able to produce proteins even without functioning mitochondria, as the ribosomes responsible for protein synthesis are located in the cytoplasm. C) The cell wall would not break, as the cell wall is a structure found only in plant cells, not animal cells. D) The cell would not become green, as the chloroplasts responsible for the green color in plants are a different organelle from the mitochondria.

questions.question_text: Why can plant cells maintain their shape even when placed in water?

options.text: Because they have a rigid cell wall

questions.explanation_correct: Plant cells can maintain their shape when placed in water because they have a rigid cell wall. The cell wall is a tough, protective layer outside the cell membrane that gives the cell structure and support, allowing it to resist changes in shape or size.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct. Plant cells have a rigid cell wall made of cellulose, which surrounds the cell membrane. This cell wall gives the plant cell a fixed shape and structure, even when placed in water. The other options (A, C, and D) are not directly related to the ability of plant cells to maintain their shape in water.

questions.question_text: A cell is observed to have a cell wall, large central vacuole, and chloroplasts. This cell most likely belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: The cell most likely belongs to a plant, specifically a leaf, because plant cells have a cell wall, a large central vacuole, and chloroplasts. These structures are unique to plant cells and help them perform vital functions like photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell does not belong to a human muscle, fish scale, or insect wing. These cell types do not have a cell wall, large central vacuole, or chloroplasts, which are the key features observed in this cell. Only plant cells, such as those found in leaves, have this combination of cellular structures.

questions.question_text: The Golgi body packages proteins. These packaged proteins are then:

options.text: Secreted out of the cell or used within the cell

questions.explanation_correct: The Golgi body packages proteins produced by the endoplasmic reticulum, and then these packaged proteins are either secreted out of the cell or used within the cell. This is the main function of the Golgi body, so option C is the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Golgi body does not destroy the proteins it packages, nor does it send them to the nucleus. It also does not convert proteins to starch. The Golgi body's role is to package proteins and then send them out of the cell or use them within the cell, which is why option C is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: The cell membrane is described as 'selectively permeable'. This means it:

options.text: Allows all substances to pass through
Does not allow any substance to pass through
Allows only certain substances to pass through

questions.explanation_correct: The cell membrane is 'selectively permeable' because it allows only certain substances to pass through, while blocking others. This allows the cell to control what goes in and out, maintaining its internal environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option C is correct because the cell membrane acts as a barrier that regulates the movement of substances in and out of the cell. It is not completely open (option A) or completely closed (option B). The cell membrane is selectively permeable, meaning it only allows certain substances to pass through based on the cell's needs. Option D about the membrane only working during the day is incorrect, as the cell membrane functions continuously to maintain the cell's internal environment.

questions.question_text: Why do unicellular organisms like Amoeba not need a circulatory system?

options.text: Because exchange of materials can happen directly through cell membrane
Because they do not need oxygen

questions.explanation_correct: Unicellular organisms like Amoeba do not need a circulatory system because they can directly exchange materials like nutrients and oxygen through their cell membrane. Since they are made of just one cell, the materials can easily diffuse in and out of the cell without needing a complex transport system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unicellular organisms like Amoeba do not have a heart, so option A is incorrect. They also need oxygen to survive, so option D is wrong. Option B is incorrect because living in water alone does not mean they don't need a circulatory system - many multicellular aquatic organisms like fish have a circulatory system. The correct answer is option C, because the small size of unicellular organisms allows them to directly exchange materials through their cell membrane without needing a separate circulatory system.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a part of the cell theory?

options.text: All living things are made of cells
Cell is the basic unit of life
All cells arise from pre-existing cells
Cells can be created from non-living matter

questions.explanation_correct: The cell theory states that all living things are made of cells, cells are the basic unit of life, and all cells arise from pre-existing cells. However, the idea that cells can be created from non-living matter is not part of the cell theory, as cells can only be formed from other living cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that cells cannot be created from non-living matter. This is because the cell theory states that all cells arise from pre-existing cells, not from non-living substances. Cells are the basic building blocks of life and can only be formed through the division and growth of other living cells, not from scratch or from non-living materials.

questions.question_text: A student observes that when a cell is damaged, its contents leak out and the damaged parts are digested. Which organelle is responsible for this?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Lysosomes. Lysosomes are small sacs in the cell that contain digestive enzymes. When a cell is damaged, the contents of the lysosomes are released, and they digest the damaged parts of the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because mitochondria (option A) are the powerhouses of the cell, ribosomes (option B) are responsible for protein synthesis, and the Golgi body (option D) is involved in packaging and distributing the cell's products. Lysosomes are the organelles that contain digestive enzymes and are responsible for breaking down and digesting the damaged parts of the cell when it is injured or dies.

questions.question_text: Plant cells store excess water in a large central vacuole. What is the advantage of this?

options.text: It maintains cell turgidity and provides support

questions.explanation_correct: The large central vacuole in plant cells stores excess water, which helps maintain cell turgidity and provide structural support to the plant. This is important for keeping the plant upright and rigid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The large central vacuole does not directly help in protein synthesis (option A) or respiration (option C). It also does not protect the plant against diseases (option D). The main advantage of the central vacuole is that it stores excess water, which keeps the plant cells turgid and provides structural support to the plant.

questions.question_text: In a cell that is actively producing and secreting enzymes, which organelles would be most abundant?
questions.explanation_correct: In a cell that is actively producing and secreting enzymes, ribosomes and Golgi bodies would be most abundant. Ribosomes are the organelles responsible for protein synthesis, and the Golgi body is involved in packaging and secreting proteins like enzymes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct because chloroplasts and vacuoles are more abundant in plant cells, lysosomes are involved in digestion and waste removal, and the cell wall and cell membrane are structural components of the cell, not directly involved in enzyme production and secretion.

questions.question_text: The nucleus contains chromatin which condenses to form chromosomes during cell division. The main function of chromosomes is to:

options.text: Carry genetic information from parent to offspring

questions.explanation_correct: The main function of chromosomes is to carry genetic information from parent to offspring. Chromosomes contain the DNA that stores the hereditary information needed to make proteins and direct the cell's activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The main function of chromosomes is not to produce energy for the cell, synthesize proteins directly, or store food. Chromosomes contain the genetic material that directs all the activities and functions of the cell. They carry this genetic information from parent to offspring, passing on traits and characteristics from one generation to the next.

questions.question_text: Which organelle has a double membrane structure?
questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria have a double membrane structure, with an inner membrane that is folded into cristae. This unique double membrane structure is what allows mitochondria to produce energy for the cell through cellular respiration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct because: Ribosomes have a single membrane structure, not a double membrane; Lysosomes and vacuoles have a single membrane that surrounds them; and chloroplasts (not mentioned in the options) have a double membrane, but this is a plant cell organelle, not an animal cell organelle like mitochondria.

questions.question_text: Green color of leaves is due to the presence of:
questions.explanation_correct: The green color of leaves is due to the presence of chloroplasts, which contain the green pigment chlorophyll. Chloroplasts are the organelles in plant cells that help plants make their own food through photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mitochondria are the powerhouses of the cell and are responsible for producing energy, but they do not contain chlorophyll and are not the reason for the green color of leaves. Vacuoles are storage compartments in plant cells, and the cell wall is the protective outer layer, but neither of these are the source of the green color.

questions.question_text: Rough endoplasmic reticulum differs from smooth endoplasmic reticulum because it has:
questions.explanation_correct: Rough endoplasmic reticulum (rER) has ribosomes attached to it, which are responsible for protein synthesis. This is the key difference between rER and smooth endoplasmic reticulum (sER), which does not have ribosomes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct because the rough endoplasmic reticulum (rER) is specifically defined by having ribosomes attached to it. It does not have mitochondria, Golgi bodies, or lysosomes attached. The presence of ribosomes is the key feature that distinguishes rER from smooth endoplasmic reticulum (sER).

questions.question_text: Which plastid type stores starch?
questions.explanation_correct: Leucoplasts, a type of plastid, are the organelles that store starch. They are the storage units of the plant cell and are responsible for accumulating various colorless substances like starch, oils, and proteins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C) Leucoplast. Chloroplasts are the plastids that contain chlorophyll and are responsible for photosynthesis, while chromoplasts contain pigments and give color to fruits and flowers. Leucoplasts, on the other hand, are the plastids that store starch, which is the correct answer for this question.

questions.question_text: The small, dense body present inside the nucleus is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The small, dense body present inside the nucleus is called the nucleolus. The nucleolus is responsible for the production of ribosomes, which are important for protein synthesis in the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is the nucleolus. The nucleolus is a small, dense structure inside the nucleus that is involved in the production of ribosomes. The other options are not correct - chromosomes are the structures that contain the genetic material, chromatin is the material that makes up the chromosomes, and cytoplasm is the jelly-like substance outside the nucleus.

questions.question_text: Robert Hooke discovered cells by observing a thin slice of cork under a microscope.
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke discovered cells in 1665 when he observed a thin slice of cork under a microscope. He saw many small compartments or 'cells' that made up the cork, which led to the discovery of the basic unit of life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is not correct. Robert Hooke did not discover cells by observing a plant slice, but rather a thin slice of cork. Cork is not a plant, but the bark of the oak tree. Hooke's observation of the small compartments or 'cells' in the cork was a major scientific discovery that led to the development of the cell theory.

questions.question_text: According to cell theory, cells can arise spontaneously from non-living matter.
questions.explanation_correct: The cell theory states that all living things are made of cells, and all cells arise from pre-existing cells. This means that cells cannot arise spontaneously from non-living matter, as the theory states that cells can only come from other cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell theory does not state that cells can arise spontaneously from non-living matter. This is because cells are the basic units of life, and they can only be formed from other pre-existing cells. Cells cannot simply appear out of nothing or from non-living things.

questions.question_text: The nucleus is the control center of the cell.
questions.explanation_correct: The nucleus is the control center of the cell. It contains the genetic material (DNA) that provides instructions for all the cell's activities and functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nucleus is not just any part of the cell. It is the control center that directs all the cell's activities and functions. The genetic material (DNA) is stored in the nucleus, which provides the instructions for the cell to work properly.

questions.question_text: Ribosomes are called the powerhouse of the cell.
questions.explanation_correct: Ribosomes are not the powerhouse of the cell. The powerhouse of the cell is the mitochondria, which are responsible for producing energy for the cell through a process called cellular respiration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'Ribosomes are called the powerhouse of the cell' is incorrect. Ribosomes are actually the organelles in the cell that are responsible for protein synthesis, not energy production. The powerhouse of the cell is the mitochondria, which are the organelles that produce energy for the cell through a process called cellular respiration.

questions.question_text: Animal cells have a cell wall made of cellulose.
questions.explanation_correct: Animal cells do not have a cell wall made of cellulose. Cell walls are only present in plant cells, not animal cells. Animal cells have a cell membrane instead, which is made of lipids and proteins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'Animal cells have a cell wall made of cellulose' is false. Cell walls are a structural feature found in plant cells, not animal cells. Animal cells have a cell membrane instead, which is made of lipids and proteins and does not contain cellulose.

questions.question_text: Chloroplasts are found in all plant cells including root cells.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is false because chloroplasts are found only in the green parts of a plant, such as the leaves, stems, and some flowers. They are not present in root cells, which are underground and do not contain chlorophyll.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Many students may think that chloroplasts are found in all plant cells, including root cells. However, this is not true. Chloroplasts are specialized organelles that contain chlorophyll and are responsible for photosynthesis. They are only found in the green, above-ground parts of the plant, such as the leaves and stems. Root cells do not contain chloroplasts as they are located underground and do not need to carry out photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Lysosomes contain digestive enzymes that can break down worn-out organelles.
questions.explanation_correct: Lysosomes are organelles that contain digestive enzymes that can break down worn-out or damaged organelles. This helps recycle and reuse the components of the cell, making lysosomes important for cell maintenance and function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Lysosomes are the 'recycling centers' of the cell. They contain powerful digestive enzymes that can break down and digest old or worn-out organelles, as well as any foreign particles that enter the cell. This helps the cell get rid of waste and reuse the components, keeping the cell healthy and functioning properly.

questions.question_text: Paramecium is an example of a multicellular organism.
questions.explanation_correct: Paramecium is a single-celled organism, so it is an example of a unicellular organism, not a multicellular organism. Multicellular organisms have many cells that work together, like plants and animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Paramecium is a single-celled organism, which means it is made up of only one cell. Multicellular organisms, on the other hand, are made up of many cells that work together, like plants and animals. So Paramecium is not an example of a multicellular organism.

questions.question_text: The cell membrane allows all substances to pass through freely.
questions.explanation_correct: The cell membrane is selectively permeable, meaning it allows only certain substances to pass through freely while blocking others. It controls what enters and leaves the cell, maintaining the right balance of nutrients, gases, and other materials inside the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell membrane is not completely permeable to all substances. It acts as a gatekeeper, regulating the movement of materials in and out of the cell. Some substances can pass through freely, but others are blocked or allowed to pass only in controlled amounts. This selective permeability is important for maintaining the cell's internal environment and supporting its functions.

questions.question_text: Centrioles are present in animal cells but absent in most plant cells.
questions.explanation_correct: Centrioles are present in animal cells but absent in most plant cells. This is because animal cells use centrioles to help separate chromosomes during cell division, while plant cells use a different structure called the cell plate to divide.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Centrioles are small structures found in the cytoplasm of animal cells that help the cell divide. Plant cells usually do not have centrioles because they have a cell wall that provides structural support, so they use a different method to divide the cell during reproduction.

questions.question_text: The cell was discovered by _____ in the year 1665.
questions.explanation_correct: The cell was discovered by Robert Hooke in 1665. This is correct because Hooke was the first person to observe and describe cells when he looked at a sample of cork under a microscope.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell was not discovered by someone else in a different year. The accepted answer is 'Robert Hooke' because he was the scientist who first discovered and described cells in 1665 when looking at a sample of cork under a microscope.

questions.question_text: The _____ is called the control center of the cell as it contains genetic material.
questions.explanation_correct: The nucleus is called the control center of the cell because it contains the genetic material, or DNA, which carries the instructions for all the cell's activities. The nucleus controls and regulates the functions of the entire cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'nucleus'. The nucleus is the control center of the cell because it contains the genetic material, or DNA, that provides the instructions for the cell to function. This genetic material in the nucleus is responsible for controlling all the activities and processes that happen within the cell.

questions.question_text: _____ are called the powerhouse of the cell because they produce energy.
questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria are called the powerhouse of the cell because they are the organelles that produce energy for the cell through a process called cellular respiration. This energy is essential for the cell to carry out its various functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'Mitochondria'. Mitochondria are the organelles in the cell that produce energy, so they are called the powerhouse of the cell. Other organelles like ribosomes and Golgi bodies have different functions and are not considered the powerhouse.

questions.question_text: Proteins are synthesized by tiny organelles called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Proteins are synthesized by tiny organelles called ribosomes. Ribosomes are the organelles responsible for making proteins in the cell, so they are the correct answer to this question.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is ribosomes. Ribosomes are tiny organelles found in the cytoplasm of cells. They are the sites where proteins are synthesized or made. So the blank should be filled with the word 'ribosomes' to correctly complete the sentence.

questions.question_text: The rigid outer covering of plant cells made of cellulose is called the _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The rigid outer covering of plant cells is called the cell wall. The cell wall is made of cellulose, which gives the plant cell its sturdy structure and shape. This cell wall is unique to plant cells and not found in animal cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'cell wall'. The cell wall is the rigid outer covering of plant cells that is made of cellulose. It is not the correct answer to say 'cell membrane', as the cell membrane is a different structure that surrounds the cell and controls what enters and leaves the cell.

questions.question_text: _____ contain the green pigment chlorophyll and are the site of photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_correct: Chloroplasts are the organelles in plant cells that contain the green pigment chlorophyll. This pigment is responsible for the green color of plants and is the site where photosynthesis takes place, allowing plants to produce their own food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Chloroplasts'. Chloroplasts are the organelles found in plant cells that contain chlorophyll and are the site of photosynthesis. Other cell organelles like mitochondria, ribosomes, and the Golgi body are not responsible for photosynthesis. The answer should be provided in the exact format 'Chloroplasts'.

questions.question_text: _____ are called suicide bags because they can digest the cell's own components.
questions.explanation_correct: Lysosomes are called 'suicide bags' because they contain powerful digestive enzymes that can break down the cell's own components if the cell is damaged or needs to recycle materials.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'Lysosomes'. Lysosomes are cell organelles that contain digestive enzymes, and they are called 'suicide bags' because they can break down the cell's own contents if the cell is damaged or needs to recycle materials. Other cell organelles like mitochondria or ribosomes do not have this 'suicide bag' function.

questions.question_text: Amoeba is an example of a _____ organism as it consists of only one cell.
questions.explanation_correct: Amoeba is a unicellular organism because it consists of only a single cell. Unicellular organisms are made up of just one cell and can carry out all the basic functions of life, unlike multicellular organisms which have many specialized cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'unicellular'. Amoeba is a single-celled organism, so it is considered a unicellular organism. Multicellular organisms, on the other hand, are made up of many specialized cells that work together as a whole. Since Amoeba has only one cell, it is classified as a unicellular organism.

questions.question_text: The _____ is a selectively permeable membrane that controls what enters and leaves the cell.
questions.explanation_correct: The cell membrane is a selectively permeable membrane that controls what enters and leaves the cell. This means it allows certain substances to pass through while blocking others, to maintain the proper balance and conditions inside the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'cell membrane'. The cell membrane is a thin, flexible structure that surrounds the cell and acts as a barrier, controlling what goes in and out of the cell. It is made up of phospholipids and proteins. The cell membrane is essential for the proper functioning and survival of the cell.

questions.question_text: The _____ packages and modifies proteins before they are secreted from the cell.
questions.explanation_correct: The Golgi body is responsible for packaging and modifying proteins that are made by the cell. It takes these proteins and prepares them to be sent out of the cell, so the Golgi body plays a key role in the secretion of proteins from the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell membrane does not package and modify proteins. That is the job of the Golgi body, which receives proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum, modifies them, and then packages them into vesicles to be sent out of the cell. The Golgi body is the correct answer in the 'fill in the blank' format.

questions.question_text: Plant cells have a large _____ that stores water, minerals, and waste products.
questions.explanation_correct: Plant cells have a large central vacuole that stores water, minerals, and waste products. This large, fluid-filled sac takes up a lot of space in the plant cell and helps maintain the cell's shape and structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'central vacuole'. Plant cells do not have a 'nucleus' as the blank space asks for. The nucleus is present in both plant and animal cells, but it is not the large structure that stores water, minerals, and waste products. That role is played by the central vacuole, a large organelle unique to plant cells.

questions.question_text: The jelly-like substance between the cell membrane and nucleus is called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The jelly-like substance between the cell membrane and nucleus is called the cytoplasm. The cytoplasm is a thick, gel-like fluid that contains all the organelles and structures of the cell, allowing them to function properly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'cytoplasm'. The cytoplasm is the jelly-like substance that fills the inside of the cell, between the cell membrane and the nucleus. It is not the nucleus, which is the control center of the cell, or the cell membrane, which is the outer layer that controls what goes in and out of the cell.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following parts of a cell from outermost to innermost:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from outermost to innermost is: cell wall (in plants), cell membrane, cytoplasm, and nucleus. This is because the cell wall is the outermost layer in plant cells, followed by the cell membrane, then the cytoplasm, and finally the nucleus at the center.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, cell wall (in plants). This is wrong because the nucleus is not the outermost part of the cell. The cell wall (in plants) is the outermost layer, followed by the cell membrane, then the cytoplasm, and finally the nucleus at the center.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following events in the discovery and development of cell biology in chronological order:
ordering_items: Microscopes were improved to see living cells
Anton van Leeuwenhoek observed living organisms
correct_answer: Anton van Leeuwenhoek observed living organisms
Microscopes were improved to see living cells
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is 'Robert Hooke discovered cells', 'Anton van Leeuwenhoek observed living organisms', 'Microscopes were improved to see living cells', and finally 'Cell theory was proposed'. This makes sense because Hooke observed cells first, then Leeuwenhoek saw tiny living organisms, and later microscopes became more powerful to study cells, leading to the development of the cell theory.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be 'Cell theory was proposed', 'Robert Hooke discovered cells', 'Microscopes were improved to see living cells', and 'Anton van Leeuwenhoek observed living organisms'. This is wrong because the cell theory could only be proposed after cells were first discovered by Hooke, and microscopes were improved to see living cells in more detail, which allowed scientists like Leeuwenhoek to observe tiny organisms.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps of protein synthesis and secretion in correct order:
ordering_items: Proteins are packaged by Golgi body
Proteins are secreted out of the cell
correct_answer: Proteins are packaged by Golgi body
Proteins are secreted out of the cell
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of protein synthesis and secretion is: 1) Proteins are synthesized by ribosomes, 2) Proteins move through endoplasmic reticulum, 3) Proteins are packaged by Golgi body, and 4) Proteins are secreted out of the cell. This is the step-by-step process that proteins go through to be produced and released from the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Proteins are packaged by Golgi body, Proteins are synthesized by ribosomes, Proteins are secreted out of the cell, Proteins move through endoplasmic reticulum. This is incorrect because proteins must first be synthesized by ribosomes, then move through the endoplasmic reticulum, before they can be packaged by the Golgi body and finally secreted out of the cell.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following from smallest to largest:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from smallest to largest is: Cell organelle, Cell, Organ, Multicellular organism. This makes sense because cell organelles are the smallest functional units within a cell, followed by the cell itself, then the organ (made up of many cells), and finally the multicellular organism (made up of many organs).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Multicellular organism, Cell, Cell organelle, Organ. This is not correct because a multicellular organism is the largest entity, made up of many organs, which are made up of many cells, which in turn contain cell organelles as the smallest parts. The order should go from smallest to largest, not the other way around.

questions.question_text: Arrange the types of plastids based on their function from photosynthesis to storage:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is Chloroplasts, Chromoplasts, Leucoplasts because chloroplasts are responsible for photosynthesis, chromoplasts store pigments that give color to flowers and fruits, and leucoplasts store substances like starch, oil, and protein for the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is Chloroplasts, Chromoplasts, Leucoplasts. Chloroplasts are the main photosynthetic organelles in plant cells. Chromoplasts contain pigments that give color to flowers and fruits. Leucoplasts are non-pigmented plastids that store substances like starch, oil, and protein for the plant. The order should be from the plastid responsible for photosynthesis to the ones responsible for storage.
